pros: Hospital being updated/upgraded, more services being offered.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Freehold, NJ
pros: The people we work with are fantastic. It's like a second family. There are a few bad apples in the bunch, as with any job, but over all the people are amazing.
cons: The aforementioned 'bad apples', are really bad. it is clear to see where all the bad reviews and bad reputation stems from. It shows how so few people can have such a huge impact on public perception. Also, the equipment, or lack thereof on several units is extremely difficult to work around. also, the staffing issues are a tremendous source of 'cons', stress, and burnout. But I know that you are trying to fix that.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in West Freehold, NJ
pros: Small community hospital where everyone knows you
cons: Management. Administration. Too much value on patient surveys. 403b contribution is laughable.

pros: My current manager, Donna Keeler, always makes herself accessible. She listens to your concerns and is proactive. She has a clear vision for the unit and communicates it effectively to the team. The teamwork is also exceptional. the group of individuals I am working with work together as if they were a family. We care for the well-being of the patients and of one another. I have seen more teamwork here than in any other place I have previously worked. It feels good to come to work and know that your colleagues will be there to back you up.
cons: Coming from a large teaching facility, I see a difference in the medical care. I have, for example, noticed failure to treat conditions such as sepsis in a rather aggressive manner on the part of physicians in spite of nursing recommendation. For example, I recently cared for a patient that met sepsis criteria, and I recommended to the MD that we should start the patient on broad-spectrum antibiotics as soon as possible. I was shut down by the MD and told that he needed to figure out what was wrong with the patient first. Although this is not the experience I have with every physician, I do find it to be a common experience, and it is frustrating. I think our ED could benefit from more concise policies regarding medical emergencies based on what the latest medical and nursing research is showing.

pros: Everyone is friendly and will respond positively to questions.

job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Freehold, NJ
pros: As someone who has worked in the non-profit healthcare sector for several years, prior to starting at CentraState- I am continuously blown away by how truly wonderful the organization is. The transparency, ethics, and earnestness of our leadership is truly commendable and is something I've never seen before in a company of this size.  It makes my job as a recruiter so much easier to be able to talk to candidates about how great the company culture is and truly mean it.  Our hiring managers always have our patients' and employees' best interest at heart, and leadership is always looking for ways we can improve in the areas of patient care, employee satisfaction, and technology.  I wanted to wait to review CS until after I had been here at least a year, and now that I've been here awhile, I'm happy to say that my positive impression hasn't changed.
cons: Sometimes it can be difficult to find parking during certain times at the medical center, but I know that as soon as the solar panel construction is complete, this shouldn't be an issue.

pros: Co-workers are  caring and kind
cons: Administrator can't make a decision if her life depended on it, would never be able to step in and do ANY Bench work. Other lab managers tend to show favoritism to certain employees, seniority is unheard of, if you stand up for yourself you are labeled. New Manager is brass and curses at her employees telling them if they don't like change to get a job at Walmart or Sams Club. Very disrespectful in her words to employees. Everyone needs their job so who's going to stand up to this bully? Nobody! Does Administration care? Probably not, weed out the complainers and hire new employees at less pay!

pros: They include a free gym membership when you start working there and promise you high wages in the aquatics department.
cons:
You need to be lifeguard and WSI (water safety instructor) certified in order to get the job, which is over $300 a class. They do not pay to get you recertified, you have to pay part of it. And once you're certified in both YOU need to go out there and get private lessons with people since there aren't actual group lessons taught in the pool. 
I never got a key to swipe in either, so that was a buzz kill too.

pros: Everyone one there is very friendly and believes in team work which is very great. I work as a utility person I am the only woman and the rest are guys. I am very thankful for the guys I work with they are very helpful and understanding there are certain things that I can't lift because they're too heavy and they are willing to step in to help me at any time. I love working with them they have taught me a lot and how to work safe in my job. They guys are the best.
cons: I don't have any

job_title: Social Services Director in Freehold, NJ
pros: I have not been with the company too long but what I have observed in a very short time is that employees are actually appreciated. I’ve worked in health care for a while, the facility issues are basically the same no matter where you go. But the huge difference is the support you do or do not receive. My Current team supports one another and my administrators actually care about what their employees think and how they feel.  I look forward to many many years with my new Centrastate family.
cons: I haven’t experienced any cons as of yet

pros: I was a student as this hospital. I was lucky enough to land job (not easy, I have heard) I was so happy to get hands on experience and the amazing training from management and co workers.

pros: Working at centrastate hospital has showed me once again that an organization can work as a team and as a family. The staff were amazing during my orientation week and the communication was non stop. My department welcomed me with open arms and my training was always on point. I never felt like I had a question unanswered , and if one came up everyone was right there for me.
cons: The 6 months wait to use PTO

pros:
Corporate policies are fair, and corporate climate great.
Unlikely to be fired without substantial cause.
cons: Laboratory has poor upper management. The failure of management to staff according to work flow, restructure lab stations to be conducive to quick work flow, and the implementation of new (but ineffective and poorly integrated) computers and analyzers decreases the labs ability to perform and causes conflict between the lab and our clients. Bonuses and raises are a joke.

pros: Wellness Center and gym have great programs.
cons: There is no recognition towards employees and management lacks the ability to properly communicate with their staff, and for a small hospital that's inexcusable. Their processes are so outdated compared to other hospitals which is kind of scary for employees and patients. Growth? That's not even a possibility because a) people who can't do their job are given immunity and take advantage of that and b) they don't try to help you grow. In regards to being admitted to the hospital, go elsewhere because your safety should be your top priority.
